question: For a derivative transaction that is mapped to the commodity risk category and has more than one material risk driver (including transactions referred to in Article 277(3)), how must an institution determine (i) whether the transaction is mapped once or multiple times across risk categories, and (ii) which risk driver basis is then used to assign the transaction to a hedging set within the commodity risk category?
gold_answer: An institution must first decide how many risk-category mappings are required for the derivative transaction, and then—once the transaction is mapped to the commodity risk category—assign it to a commodity hedging set using the appropriate risk-driver basis. [#SRC:820ffbb74005c855] For derivatives with more than one material risk driver, the institution must map the transaction to more than one risk category as a derogation from paragraph 2. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] If all material risk drivers fall within a single risk category, the transaction is mapped only once to that category, using the most material of those risk drivers as the basis for that single mapping. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] If the material risk drivers span different risk categories, the transaction is mapped once to each relevant risk category for which it has at least one material risk driver, and the mapping within each category is based on the most material risk driver in that category. [#TGT:28d975e9bccdd9ad] After the transaction is mapped to the commodity risk category (including for transactions referred to in Article 277(3)), it must be assigned to one of the commodity hedging sets based on the nature of its primary risk driver, or—where applicable—the most material risk driver in the commodity risk category. [#SRC:820ffbb74005c855]
source_text: (e) transactions mapped to the commodity risk category shall be assigned to one of the following hedging sets on the basis of the nature of their primary risk driver or the most material risk driver in the given risk category for transactions referred to in Article 277(3) :
target_text: By way of derogation from paragraph 2 , institutions shall map derivative transactions that have more than one material risk driver to more than one risk category. Where all the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to the same risk category, institutions shall only be required to map that transaction once to that risk category on the basis of the most material of those risk drivers. Where the material risk drivers of one of those transactions belong to different risk categories, institutions shall map that transaction once to each risk category for which the transaction has at least one material risk driver, on the basis of the most material of the risk drivers in that risk category.

question: If senior management is putting names to the model risk jobs (for model owners, model users, and control/compliance) under the board’s documented model risk framework, what extra thing should the firm do when those jobs sit in senior management functions, and how does that fit with the board and senior management’s duty to challenge model outputs?
gold_answer: When the firm is allocating model risk management responsibilities into senior management functions, it should not only follow the board’s documented framework and senior management’s role in running it, but also take into account the relevant prescribed responsibilities in the PRA Rulebook’s ‘Allocation of Responsibilities’ 4.1 or 5.2. [#SRC:d4070cd7428fcd33] [#TGT:51ea2b168d63b6d3] The board of directors should set up and document the framework for managing model risk, and senior management is responsible for executing and maintaining it, including assigning roles and responsibilities to model owners, model users, and control and compliance functions. [#SRC:d4070cd7428fcd33] Because the Target text specifically addresses assignments to senior management functions, the firm should consider the prescribed responsibilities in the cited ‘Allocation of Responsibilities’ sections when making those allocations. [#TGT:51ea2b168d63b6d3] Those allocations should also support the expectation that the board of directors and senior management provide challenge to model outputs and understand model capabilities, limitations, and the impact of model uncertainty for the most material models and aggregate outputs, so the assigned responsibilities enable that challenge and understanding in practice. [#SRC:d4070cd7428fcd33]
source_text: P2.1 Board of directors and senior management responsibility: 5 The board of directors should establish a framework for the management of model risk and this should be adequately documented. Senior management is responsible for the execution and maintenance of the framework and should designate the roles and responsibilities for the framework to model owners, model users, and control and compliance functions. 6 The board of directors and senior management are expected to provide challenge to model outputs and understand model capabilities, the model limitations, and the potential impact of model uncertainty for the most material models and the aggregate outputs.
target_text: 5. When assigning the responsibilities of the management of model risk to senior management functions, firms should consider the relevant prescribed responsibilities in ‘Allocation of Responsibilities’ 4.1 or 5.2 in the PRA Rulebook.

question: Who has to appoint the compliance officer, and how does that role connect to the rule that senior management must get written reports (at least once a year) that say whether fixes were made when problems were found?
gold_answer: The management body must appoint a compliance officer, and that compliance officer must be responsible for the compliance function and for any compliance reporting required for the firm’s obligations under the regulatory system and General Organisational Requirements 4.7. [#SRC:08b491dc52b89657] Separately, the firm must make sure its senior management receive written reports frequently and at least annually on the matters covered by the Compliance and Internal Audit and Risk Control Parts. [#TGT:37d016c3c16067f3] To connect these requirements in practice, the compliance officer’s responsibility for compliance reporting should be used to drive the preparation and delivery of those written reports to senior management on the required schedule. [#SRC:08b491dc52b89657] [#TGT:37d016c3c16067f3] The written reports to senior management must also indicate whether appropriate remedial measures were taken when deficiencies occurred, so the reporting overseen by the compliance officer needs to include both identification of deficiencies and an update on whether remediation has been completed. [#TGT:37d016c3c16067f3] In short, appointment by the management body establishes who owns compliance reporting, and the senior-management reporting rule sets the minimum frequency and the requirement to report on remediation status. [#SRC:08b491dc52b89657] [#TGT:37d016c3c16067f3]
source_text: (2) a compliance officer is appointed by the management body and that compliance officer is responsible for the compliance function and for any compliance reporting required in relation to its obligations under the regulatory system and General Organisational Requirements 4.7 ;
target_text: A firm must ensure that its senior management receive on a frequent basis, and at least annually, written reports on the matters covered by the Compliance and Internal Audit and Risk Control Parts . Such written reports must indicate whether the appropriate remedial measures have been taken in the event of any deficiencies.

question: If a firm has client accounts or trust accounts held for beneficiaries that might have eligible deposits, how should those accounts be labelled, and what does the PRA expect the firm to be able to send to the PRA or the FSCS (and by when) if asked?
gold_answer: The firm needs to label (mark) beneficiary-held accounts—specifically including client accounts and trust accounts—so that those accounts can be spotted right away as accounts that contain or may contain eligible deposits. [#TGT:68113e9f6b9da4d1] Beyond putting that marking in place, the PRA expects the firm to be able to produce account information that separates eligible accounts from ineligible accounts, so the two categories are clearly distinguished in what is provided to supervisors or the compensation scheme. [#SRC:abfeb4bf0c334fbc] The firm must be able to provide those details to the PRA or the FSCS in a format that matches the relevant rule and the PRA’s statement, rather than in an arbitrary internal format. [#SRC:abfeb4bf0c334fbc] Timing is also part of the expectation: once the PRA or the FSCS asks for the information, the firm must be able to make the separately identified eligible and/or ineligible account details available within twelve hours from the point of that request. [#SRC:abfeb4bf0c334fbc] In practice, the marking requirement and the twelve-hour delivery capability work together to support immediate identification and rapid reporting for these beneficiary-held accounts. [#TGT:68113e9f6b9da4d1] [#SRC:abfeb4bf0c334fbc]
source_text: The PRA expects that in compliance with the requirement in Depositor Protection 11.1 to 11.2 to mark eligible deposits/accounts ‘in a way that allows for the immediate identification of such deposits’, a firm must be able to make the details of such eligible and/or ineligible accounts (separately identified) available to the PRA or FSCS in a format consistent with the relevant rule and this statement and within twelve hours from the point of a request from the PRA or the FSCS.
target_text: A firm must mark accounts (including client accounts and trust accounts) which are held on behalf of beneficiaries and which contain or may contain eligible deposits in a way that allows immediate identification of such accounts.

question: If a firm thinks it might use the Bank of England’s lending facilities (like the Discount Window Facility), what should it do when it checks whether it has enough capital, funding, and liquidity for a solvent exit, including how it values assets and runs sensitivity analysis?
gold_answer: If the firm anticipates using the Bank of England’s lending facilities (for example, the Discount Window Facility), it should factor that expectation into its overall view of whether it has adequate resources for a solvent exit. [#TGT:29aef3477fc07890] The firm’s check must still be a full assessment of financial resources—capital, funding, and liquidity—sized to absorb the complete costs of exiting solvently and to meet all liabilities to depositors (and other creditors as applicable). [#SRC:35122617de21cc35] That assessment needs to be grounded in realistic exit valuations of the firm’s assets and liabilities, not optimistic assumptions. [#SRC:35122617de21cc35] It also needs appropriate analysis, including sensitivity analyses of factors that could affect how much resource is required, and analysis of any balance sheet items that may be hard to transfer or sell once the main deposit and lending books have been disposed of. [#SRC:35122617de21cc35] Bringing these together, the firm should evaluate whether its capital, funding, and liquidity position—taking into account any anticipated facility usage—remains sufficient under the realistic valuations and sensitivity scenarios it has run to cover exit costs and liabilities. [#SRC:35122617de21cc35] [#TGT:29aef3477fc07890]
source_text: financial resources, including capital, funding, and liquidity, 55 to absorb the full costs of the solvent exit and meet all liabilities to depositors (and other creditors as applicable), with realistic exit valuations of assets and liabilities and appropriate analysis conducted (such as sensitivity analyses of factors that may impact the resources needed, and an analysis of any balance sheet items which may be difficult to transfer or sell after the main deposit and lending books have been disposed of)
target_text: 55. This includes whether the firm anticipates the use of the Bank of England’s lending facilities (eg Discount Window Facility). See the ‘Bank of England Market Operations Guide’ for further details.

question: If a related undertaking’s items are treated as not effectively available to cover the group SCR (including when the related undertaking is a third country insurance undertaking or an insurance holding company), what does that mean for whether the related Solvency II undertaking’s own funds can be counted in the group solvency calculation?
gold_answer: If items of a related undertaking are assumed not to be effectively available to cover the group SCR, that assumption frames the availability assessment for group SCR coverage across several types of related undertakings, including Solvency II undertakings, third country insurance undertakings, third country reinsurance undertakings, insurance holding companies, and mixed financial holding companies. [#TGT:03e8a5e9bd172697] Where, in that setting, certain own funds eligible for the SCR of a related Solvency II undertaking cannot effectively be made available to cover the SCR of the participating Solvency II undertaking for which group solvency is calculated, those own funds must not be included in the group solvency calculation. [#SRC:cbb5ec092d926613] The only stated exception is narrow: the own funds may be included only if, and only to the extent that, they are eligible for covering the SCR of the related undertaking itself. [#SRC:cbb5ec092d926613] Operationally, you would (1) confirm the entity is a “related undertaking” within the types listed for the non-availability assumption, and (2) treat any own funds that are not effectively available for group SCR as excluded unless they still qualify for the related undertaking’s SCR coverage. [#TGT:03e8a5e9bd172697] This ensures group solvency reflects only own funds that are effectively available for group SCR purposes, with limited carry-through based on the related undertaking’s SCR eligibility. [#SRC:cbb5ec092d926613]

question: If you are checking what a firm or FMI needs to follow, what do you do if a guideline isn’t in Appendices 1–3, and how do you treat ESMA guideline updates that came out after the end of the transition period (even if ESMA is the source of the linked materials)?

question: If a firm is working out the minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business, what should it do when it has at least one past financial year to look at, and what amount applies if it is too new to have a preceding financial year?
gold_answer: The firm should start by checking whether it has a preceding financial year, because that determines whether it uses an income-based table or a fixed amount. [#SRC:7add590aa50e6993] If the firm does have one or more preceding financial years, it must look back across those years and find its highest annual contribution income for long-term insurance business, then match that highest income level to the table so it can take the minimum guarantee fund amount shown for that income band. [#SRC:7add590aa50e6993] If the firm is too new to have a preceding financial year, it cannot apply the table method that depends on identifying the highest annual contribution income in a preceding year; in that case, the minimum guarantee fund for long-term insurance business is set at £90,000. [#TGT:57922715d15fab69] This means the same firm could have different minimum guarantee fund outcomes depending on whether it has historical annual contribution income data from a preceding financial year (table-based) or lacks that history (the £90,000 default). [#SRC:7add590aa50e6993] [#TGT:57922715d15fab69]

question: When submitting the Merger Document (including the Schedule 16 Statement) and the related explanations of change, comparability and commitments, what interim financial-position disclosure must the board make because the financial information period ends before approval of the Schedule 16 Statement, and what is the stated regulatory consequence of failing to disclose such changes?
gold_answer: In preparing and submitting the Merger Document that includes the Schedule 16 Statement (together with the explanations of change, comparability and commitments referenced alongside it), the board must address the fact that the financial information necessarily covers a period ending before the Schedule 16 Statement is approved. [#SRC:f1c8b930cd8f5ee1] Specifically, the board is required to state whether there have been any material changes to the financial position in the interim between the end of that financial-information period and the approval date. [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1] If a material change has occurred and its effect cannot be quantified, the board must still describe the change so that members understand it has been identified and is relevant to their consideration of the proposed merger. [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1] This interim-change disclosure is therefore a necessary complement to the Merger Document package (including the Schedule 16 Statement and the associated explanations) being put forward. [#SRC:f1c8b930cd8f5ee1] A failure to disclose such interim material changes is not treated as immaterial: it will be relevant to the PRA’s later consideration of the society’s application for confirmation of the merger. [#TGT:ee19b3e79f8edaa1]
source_text: (c) the Merger Document, including the Schedule 16 Statement, unless consent to proceed by way of board resolution is being sought in respect of the transferee society, together with the explanations of change, comparability and commitments referred to in paragraph 3.73 to 3.75 and 3.95 ;
target_text: Since the financial information will necessarily relate to a period ending somewhat before the date of approval of the Schedule 16 Statement, the board is required to state whether or not there have been any material changes to the financial position in the interim. If the effect of a change cannot be quantified, it must be described so that the members at least know that it has been identified and is relevant to their consideration of the proposed merger. Failure to disclose such changes will be relevant to the PRA’s subsequent consideration of the society’s application for confirmation of the merger (see paragraphs 3.157 , 3.169 and 3.170 ).

question: Where the PRA has deferred (in whole or in part) a class A2 member’s obligation to pay its share of a recapitalisation payment levy because payment would jeopardise the liquidity or solvency of the firm, when must the deferred amount be paid, and what is the maximum duration of any single deferral (including whether it can be renewed)?
gold_answer: A deferred contribution must be paid once making the payment no longer threatens the firm’s liquidity and solvency, and any PRA-granted deferral of a class A2 member’s share of a recapitalisation payment levy cannot run for more than six months at a time, though it may be renewed if the firm asks. [#SRC:f026573295165d20] [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b] The trigger for payment is the point at which paying the deferred amount ceases to jeopardise the liquidity and solvency of the firm, meaning the deferral is not a permanent waiver but a timing adjustment tied to the firm’s financial condition. [#SRC:f026573295165d20] The PRA’s ability to defer applies where it considers that the contributions would jeopardise the liquidity or solvency of the firm, and it may defer the obligation in whole or in part for a class A2 member in relation to a recapitalisation payment levy. [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b] Even if the liquidity/solvency concern persists, the PRA cannot grant a single deferral for longer than six months; however, the firm can request renewal, allowing the deferral to be extended through successive periods if renewed. [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b] Accordingly, compliance planning should align both the condition-based payment point and the six-month cap with potential renewal requests. [#SRC:f026573295165d20] [#TGT:9b64fbbd8245427b]
source_text: Any contributions deferred pursuant to 46.2 or 46.2A shall be paid when the payment no longer jeopardises the liquidity and solvency of the firm .
target_text: The PRA may defer, in whole or in part, a class A2 member’s obligation to pay a share of a recapitalisation payment levy if the PRA considers that such contributions would jeopardise the liquidity or solvency of the firm . Such deferral shall not be granted for a longer period than six months but may be renewed upon request of the firm .

question: When constructing a matching adjustment (MA) portfolio that includes in-payment income protection claims, how should a firm reconcile the PRA’s view that in-payment elements may be eligible where separately identifiable and managed separately with the rule that insurance or reinsurance obligations must not be split into different parts except for an eligible element, and what underwriting risk exposure limits apply to recovery time risk in that context?
gold_answer: A firm may only treat part of an income protection contract separately for MA portfolio composition where that part qualifies as an eligible element, and the PRA’s discussion of “in-payment elements” is framed as potentially eligible only when they are separately identifiable and can be organised and managed separately (including in line with regulation 4(6) of the IRPR regulations). [#SRC:aa234508c5cb946b] The general rule for this Part is that insurance or reinsurance obligations under a contract must not be split into different parts when composing the relevant portfolio, except in the case of an eligible element, so any separation of an in-payment element must fit within that exception rather than being a general permission to split obligations. [#TGT:80ba42a4e7626379] In that setting, the permitted underwriting risks connected to the portfolio of liabilities may include recovery time risk, described as the risk that policyholders receiving income protection payments take longer than expected to recover from sickness. [#SRC:aa234508c5cb946b] Unlike mortality risk, the PRA indicates there is no restriction on the exposure to recovery time risk in firms’ MA portfolios, but it also states it does not expect recognising recovery time risk to justify bringing in liabilities other than income protection claims in payment. [#SRC:aa234508c5cb946b]
source_text: Matching Adjustment 2.2(2) specifies that the permitted underwriting risks connected to the portfolio of liabilities may include recovery time risk, where this is the risk that policyholders in receipt of income protection payments take longer to recover from sickness than expected. Matching Adjustment 2.3 and 2.5 provide that in-payment elements of income protection contracts may be eligible for inclusion, where they are separately identifiable and can be organised and managed separately in accordance with regulation 4(6) of the IRPR regulations. The PRA considers that this will allow in-payment claims under both group and individual income protection policies to be permitted within MA portfolios, where the claims are not subject to future premiums. Unlike with mortality risk, there is no restriction on the exposure to recovery time risk in firms’ MA portfolios. The PRA does not expect that the inclusion of recovery time as an underwriting risk should lead to types of liabilities other than income protection claims in payment being included in MA portfolios.
target_text: For the purposes of this Part, the insurance or reinsurance obligations of an insurance or reinsurance contract must not be split into different parts when composing the relevant portfolio of insurance or reinsurance obligations , other than in the case of an eligible element .

question: If a firm is new and hasn’t finished a full financial year yet, what valuation should it use to pay periodic fees in its first fee year, and what should it use in its second fee year if it got its new or extended permission between 1 January (in its first fee year) and 1 April (in its second fee year)?
gold_answer: The firm should use projected valuation in both situations described, but the trigger conditions differ between the first and second fee years. [#TGT:bc923fb7c74a4666] [#SRC:d75ff793a1100dc6] In the first fee year, the periodic fees are paid based on the firm’s projected valuation for the first twelve months of its new business. [#TGT:bc923fb7c74a4666] For the second fee year, the projected-valuation approach applies only where the firm has not completed a full financial year by the start of the fee year and it is in its second fee year, and it received its new or extended permission relevant to the activity during the period from 1 January in its first fee year to 1 April in its second fee year. [#SRC:d75ff793a1100dc6] When those second-fee-year conditions are met, the firm should apply projected valuations in the way referenced (as set out in 3.7). [#SRC:d75ff793a1100dc6] Linking the two passages, the first-fee-year rule establishes projected valuation as the basis for periodic fees for the first twelve months of new business, and the second-fee-year rule extends the use of projected valuations into the second fee year for firms that are still without a completed full financial year and that obtained the relevant permission within the stated date window. [#TGT:bc923fb7c74a4666] [#SRC:d75ff793a1100dc6]

question: In a merger where a bonus is proposed to equalise reserves between a transferor society and a transferee society (and potentially also to pay a bonus to members of the transferee society), how should the societies determine which Merger Resolutions must include member approval of the bonus payments, taking into account the prudence condition and the prescribed-limit test based on total gross cost?
gold_answer: Member approval for any proposed bonus payment(s) must be obtained through the Merger Resolutions, and the resolution(s) that must carry that approval depend on which society’s funds are being distributed and whether the total gross cost is within the prescribed limit. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] Where a bonus is used to address differing capital ratios—such as paying members of a transferor society that has a higher capital ratio than the transferee society to help equalise the reserves brought into the combined society—the proposal still needs to be structured so that any equalisation (including any decision to also pay a bonus to members of the transferee society) is only taken forward if it is prudent to equalise reserves at a level below the transferee society’s capital ratio. [#SRC:b67dac575cd27cc6] Operationally, the Merger Resolutions should be drafted as follows: - Calculate the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es) without adjusting for prospective corporation tax recovery, and compare it to the prescribed limit. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] - If the total gross cost is within the prescribed limit, include the bonus-approval wording only in each Merger Resolution of the society whose funds are to be distributed (i.e., the paying society). [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] - If the total gross cost exceeds the prescribed limit, include the bonus-approval wording in each Merger Resolution of each participating society. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] - Ensure the rationale for any reserve equalisation (including paying both sets of members) aligns with the prudence constraint described for setting the combined society’s reserve level. [#SRC:b67dac575cd27cc6]
source_text: A bonus may, for example, be paid to the members of a transferor society with a higher capital ratio than the transferee society so as to equalise the reserves which both bring to the combined society. If it is thought desirable also to pay a bonus to the members of the transferee society, then the reserves of the combined society may be equalised at a level below the capital ratio of the transferee society, but only if it is prudent to do so. The statutory requirements for approval of bonus payments are described in paragraph 3.107 .
target_text: The members approval of bonus payments is required as part of the Merger Resolutions (see section 96(4) to (6) of the 1986 Act) and see paragraph 3.59 for the PRA’s view of what may constitute a bonus). If it exceeds that limit then it must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society. question: If a large institution’s non-performing loans and advances ratio is 5% or more, what extra templates does it have to publish each year, and when does it have to start publishing them based on the rule about two back-to-back quarters in the last four quarters before the disclosure reference date?
gold_answer: When a large institution has a non-performing loans and advances ratio that is at least 5%, it must make the additional disclosures (linked to points (c) and (f) of Article 442 of the CRR) using templates UK CR2a, UK CQ2, CQ6, UK CQ8, and columns b and d of Templates UK CQ4 and UK CQ5, following the Annex XV templates and Annex XVI instructions, and it must do so annually. [#TGT:f4069472e0482e37] The institution must begin making disclosure in line with the 5% threshold rule once it has reached or exceeded 5% in two consecutive quarters during the four quarters before the disclosure reference date. [#SRC:d188f8c0946e8de1] For the first time it discloses, the institution must include the templates that are subject to the 5% threshold if it meets the threshold on that first disclosure reference date. [#SRC:d188f8c0946e8de1] Putting these together, the annual obligation to use the specified UK templates applies when the ratio is at or above 5%, and the start point is determined by checking whether the institution hit or exceeded 5% in two back-to-back quarters in the prior four-quarter window, while also ensuring the first disclosure reference date includes the threshold-subject templates if the ratio is at or above 5% on that date. [#TGT:f4069472e0482e37] [#SRC:d188f8c0946e8de1]
source_text: Institutions shall commence disclosure in accordance with paragraph 3 where they have reached or exceeded the 5% threshold in two consecutive quarters during the four quarters prior to the reference date of the disclosure. For the reference date of the first disclosure, institutions shall disclose the templates subject to the 5% threshold if they comply with the threshold on that disclosure reference date.
target_text: In addition to the templates referred to in paragraph 22 and in order to convey sufficiently comprehensive and comparable information for users of that information to assess the risk profiles of institutions, large institutions with a ratio of gross carrying amount of non-performing loans and advances divided by the total gross carrying amount of loans and advances subject to the definition of non-performing according to Article 47a of the CRR equal to or higher than 5% shall make the disclosure required in points (c) and (f) of Article 442 of the CRR also in accordance with templates UK CR2a , UK CQ2 , CQ6 and UK CQ8 , columns b and d of Templates UK CQ4 and UK CQ5 set out in Annex XV and with the instructions set out in Annex XVI , on an annual basis.

question: When a society establishes or reviews its corporate governance arrangements, how should it decide whether to have regard to the UK Corporate Governance Code or the Combined Code, and what specific scope limitation applies to the Combined Code referenced in the materials?
gold_answer: A society that is not publicly quoted is expected, when setting up and when reassessing its corporate governance arrangements, to take into account an appropriate governance code, choosing between the UK Corporate Governance Code and the Combined Code depending on which is suitable in the circumstances. [#SRC:1da93b3de3471f0b] Where the society looks to the Combined Code, the relevant Combined Code is the version on Corporate Governance that was developed by the Corporate Governance Committee of the Financial Reporting Council and is expressly tied to accounting periods that begin before 29 June 2010. [#TGT:a3566db56919a9f0] In practical terms, this means the society’s “have regard to” exercise for the Combined Code is anchored to that identified Combined Code and its stated accounting-period applicability, rather than an unspecified or open-ended version. [#TGT:a3566db56919a9f0] The trigger for considering these codes is the society’s act of establishing and reviewing its corporate governance arrangements, and the society’s non-publicly-quoted status does not remove the expectation to consider the codes; it frames the context in which the society should select the appropriate one. [#SRC:1da93b3de3471f0b]
source_text: Although societies are not publicly quoted, they should have regard to the UK Corporate Governance Code 4 or the Combined Code 5 as appropriate when they establish and review their corporate governance arrangements.
target_text: 5. The Combined Code on Corporate Governance, developed by the Corporate Governance Committee of the Financial Reporting Council for accounting periods beginning before 29 June 2010.

question: Where a firm excludes exposures under the resolution exemption in the Large Exposures Part of the PRA Rulebook, and those exposures are not included in MREL reporting as specified in Supervisory Statement (SS) 19/13 ‘Resolution planning’, what notification is required and which June 2018 Bank of England webpage is identified for SS 19/13?
gold_answer: A firm that has excluded exposures using the resolution exemption in the Large Exposures Part of the PRA Rulebook must notify the PRA when those excluded exposures are not included in MREL reporting in the manner specified in Supervisory Statement (SS) 19/13 ‘Resolution planning’. [#SRC:5ef0f6dbfa3bd3bb] This notification trigger is tied specifically to the combination of (i) use of the resolution exemption for Large Exposures and (ii) the fact that the exposures are not captured in MREL reporting as SS 19/13 sets out, so the firm should treat the absence from MREL reporting (as specified in SS 19/13) as the condition that makes the PRA notification necessary. [#SRC:5ef0f6dbfa3bd3bb] The referenced SS 19/13 ‘Resolution planning’ is identified with a June 2018 link on the Bank of England website at www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/publication/2013/resolution-planning-ss. [#TGT:695e320d362f1655] Accordingly, the firm’s compliance action is to notify the PRA in the stated circumstances, and the SS 19/13 reference point for the MREL reporting specification is the June 2018 Bank of England webpage provided. [#SRC:5ef0f6dbfa3bd3bb] [#TGT:695e320d362f1655]
source_text: Firms that exclude exposures pursuant to the resolution exemption in the Large Exposures Part of the PRA Rulebook should notify the PRA if those exposures are not included in MREL reporting as specified in Supervisory Statement (SS) 19/13 ‘Resolution planning’ . 5
target_text: 5. June 2018: www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/publication/2013/resolution-planning-ss .

question: How should a firm align its risk-management system’s scope of covered risks with the calibration expectation that all quantifiable risks are taken into account, and which minimum risk categories must be reflected across both the SCR-related coverage and the system’s specified areas?
gold_answer: A firm should design its risk-management system so that it both (i) covers the risks relevant to the SCR calculation (and those not, or not fully, captured by that calculation) and (ii) is aligned with the expectation that all quantifiable risks to which the firm is exposed are taken into account through calibration. [#SRC:ec68cf68d094e876] [#TGT:f261181a95a3ca51] The system must be effective and embedded in the firm’s organisational structure and decision-making, with proper consideration of persons who have key functions, so that the calibration and risk coverage are operationally implemented rather than treated as a standalone exercise. [#SRC:ec68cf68d094e876] In practical terms, the firm should ensure that the risk coverage includes the risks to be included in the SCR calculation and also addresses risks that are not, or not fully, included in that calculation, while still ensuring that all quantifiable risks are taken into account. [#SRC:ec68cf68d094e876] [#TGT:f261181a95a3ca51] At a minimum, the calibration expectation explicitly includes non-life underwriting risk, life underwriting risk, health underwriting risk, market risk, credit risk, and operational risk, and the risk-management system must cover specified areas including underwriting and reserving, asset-liability management, investment risk management (notably derivatives, quasi-derivatives and similar commitments), liquidity and concentration risk management, operational risk management, and reinsurance and other risk-mitigation techniques. [#TGT:f261181a95a3ca51] [#SRC:ec68cf68d094e876]
source_text: (2) That risk-management system must: (a) be effective and well integrated into the organisational structure and decision-making processes of the firm with proper consideration of the persons who have key functions ; (b) cover the risks to be included in the calculation of the SCR as set out in Solvency Capital Requirement - General Provisions 3.3(1) , as well as the risks which are not, or not fully, included in the calculation thereof; and (c) cover at least the following areas: (i) underwriting and reserving as set out in 3.1A(1) ; (ii) asset-liability management as set out in 3.1A(2) ; (iii) investment risk management, in particular derivatives , quasi-derivatives and similar commitments, as set out in 3.1A(3) ; (iv) liquidity risk and concentration risk management: as set out in 3.1A(4) and 3.1A(5) ; (v) operational risk management as set out in 3.1A(6) ; and (vi) reinsurance and other risk-mitigation techniques as set out in 3.1A(7) .
target_text: (1) must be calibrated to ensure that all quantifiable risks to which the firm is exposed are taken into account, including at least the non-life underwriting risk , life underwriting risk , health underwriting risk , market risk , credit risk , and operational risk ;

question: For a firm that has permission to use a partial or full internal model, what quarterly submission to the PRA is required for model changes, and what specific template and instruction source must be used to provide both change details and qualitative support?
gold_answer: A firm with permission to use a partial or full internal model must provide the PRA with a quarterly submission covering model changes, and it must do so using the specified PRA template and instructions. [#SRC:6b80f0d656b136bd] The quarterly content must be a summary of both minor and major model changes provided to the PRA, reflecting the requirement tied to Article 6(3) of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook and the EIOPA Guidelines on the use of internal models. [#SRC:6b80f0d656b136bd] To meet the quarterly reporting format and information expectations, firms using an internal model must submit quarterly template QMC.01 of Chapter 9, which requires information on model changes together with supporting qualitative information. [#TGT:96395cb1453e2aa2] The submission must be prepared in line with the instructions set out in section QMC.01 of Chapter 10, which governs how the template is to be completed and what supporting qualitative detail is to accompany the model-change information. [#TGT:96395cb1453e2aa2] Taken together, this means the firm’s quarterly summary of minor and major changes is operationalized through template QMC.01 and its Chapter 10 instructions, and the deliverable is submitted to the PRA each quarter. [#SRC:6b80f0d656b136bd] [#TGT:96395cb1453e2aa2]
source_text: In accordance with Article 6(3) of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook and the EIOPA Guidelines on the use of internal models, firms with permission to use a partial or full internal model are required to provide a quarterly summary of minor and major model changes to the PRA.
target_text: Firms using an internal model must submit to the PRA quarterly template QMC.01 of Chapter 9 , specifying information on model changes and supporting qualitative information, in accordance with the instructions set out in section QMC.01 of Chapter 10 .

question: For a TWD firm, how should the firm align its capability to refresh the material components of the TWD option that require judgement with the requirement to run sensitivity analyses of key market factors, including the expected timeframe for doing so and the minimum scope of sensitivities?
gold_answer: A TWD firm should be able to use its data refresh and full plan refresh capabilities to update the material, judgement-driven components of its TWD option within a timeframe ranging from a matter of days to a matter of weeks, with the exact speed depending on the nature and extent of the stress. [#SRC:58ebd6a4c26d1aaa] In doing so, the firm’s refresh process should incorporate sensitivity analyses focused on the key market factors in the TWD scenario, as well as the assumptions and judgments that could materially affect capital and liquidity projections and RBLs. [#TGT:5fd58dcf50062ad4] Practically, this means the refresh capability is not only about updating inputs, but also about testing how changes in those key factors and related assumptions/judgments would move the firm’s projected capital and liquidity outcomes and its RBLs. [#TGT:5fd58dcf50062ad4] The sensitivity work should be included as part of the refresh of the material components that require judgement, and it should cover updates to the factors referenced for sensitivity analysis in the relevant paragraphs identified in the expectation. [#SRC:58ebd6a4c26d1aaa] The minimum expectation is that sensitivities of capital and liquidity to the specified factors are included, rather than being optional or ad hoc. [#TGT:5fd58dcf50062ad4]

question: When giving notice of an application under the Business Transfers Regulations, how should the firm(s) structure the accompanying statement and summary so recipients can understand the scheme’s effect, and what must be made available on request (including whether the internet may be used), given that the notice must go to specified categories of policyholders and certain reinsurers and should explain how and when representations are to be made to the court?
gold_answer: The firm(s) should treat the application notice as a package that both reaches the required recipients and equips them to understand the scheme and participate effectively in the court process. The notice must be sent to all policyholders of the parties and to reinsurers (or a person acting on its behalf) whose reinsurance contracts are proposed to be transferred, unless the court directs otherwise. [#TGT:c99af11004d99259] Alongside that notice, it would normally be appropriate to include a statement setting out the scheme’s terms and summarising the scheme report, drafted so that each recipient can grasp in broad terms how the scheme is likely to affect them; this is best achieved by a clear, concise summary that still contains enough detail, avoiding an overly long or hard-to-understand summary. [#SRC:763120bb6b209201] The notice and related communications should also explain how and when affected parties’ representations should be made so the court can consider them. [#TGT:c99af11004d99259] In addition, the Business Transfers Regulations require the scheme report, the notice, and the statement to be made available to anyone who requests them, and the internet may be used to provide access where it is suitable for the person making the request. [#SRC:763120bb6b209201]
source_text: It would normally be appropriate to include with the notice referred to in 2.49 above a statement setting out the terms of the scheme and containing a summary of the scheme report. Ideally every recipient should understand in broad terms from the summary how the scheme is likely to affect them. This objective will be most nearly achieved if the summary is clear and concise while containing sufficient detail for the purpose. A lengthy summary or one that was hard to understand would not be appropriate. The Business Transfers Regulations require the scheme report, the notice and the statement to be made available to anyone requesting them. The internet can be used for this purpose if it is suitable for the person making the request.
target_text: Under the Business Transfers Regulations, unless the court directs otherwise, notice of the application must be sent to all policyholders of the parties and reinsurers (or a person acting on its behalf) any of whose contracts of reinsurance are proposed to be transferred as part of the insurance business transfer scheme. It may also be appropriate to give notice to others affected, for example, to anyone with an interest in the policies being transferred who has notified the transferor of their interest. This notice, along with other communications and advertising by or and on behalf of the firm(s), should provide details of how and when any representations by affected parties should be made in order to be considered by the court.

question: If you are writing a PRA policy statement about varying approvals, which FSMA section do you cite for the requirement that the PRA and FCA publish their policy statements, and which FSMA sections do you cite for the power to vary approvals?
gold_answer: You should cite one FSMA section for the obligation to publish the policy statement, and different FSMA sections for the legal power that the policy statement is discussing. [#SRC:ad7dc485c7e56a6e] For the publication requirement, the PRA’s statement of policy is described as being issued in accordance with section 63ZD of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (FSMA), and that section is described as requiring the PRA and the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) to issue statements of their respective policies. [#SRC:ad7dc485c7e56a6e] For the underlying power on the specific topic of varying approvals, you should cite sections 63ZA or 63ZB of FSMA, because those are identified as the sections where the PRA’s and FCA’s power to vary approvals is set out. [#TGT:294fe7b55286ce9a] Using both references together makes the explanation complete: section 63ZD supports why the PRA and FCA are issuing policy statements at all, while sections 63ZA/63ZB identify where the power being covered (varying approvals) sits in FSMA. [#SRC:ad7dc485c7e56a6e] [#TGT:294fe7b55286ce9a]
source_text: This statement of policy is issued by the Prudential Regulation Authority (PRA) in accordance with section 63ZD of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (FSMA) as amended by the Financial Services (Banking Reform)Act 2013, 1 and the Bank of England and Financial Services Act 2016, which requires the PRA and the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) to issue a statement of their respective policies on:
target_text: 2. The PRA’s and FCA’s power to vary approvals are set out in Sections in sections 63ZA or 63ZB of FSMA.

question: If markets are stressed, do firms change the MA calculation method for TPs, and when can they add more to the fundamental spread than the amount worked out under 4.10–4.16 (including the kinds of add-ons mentioned in 4.16 and 4.17)?
gold_answer: When calculating TPs, the MA and FS are determined using the approach set out in Chapter 4 of the Matching Adjustment Part of the PRA rulebook, and the PRA view is that the MA calculation method should stay the same even in stress conditions. [#SRC:dd04e755dbd1506a] Even so, firms should actively consider whether the assumptions feeding into the MA and FS used for the TP calculation are still suitable under stress, including any extra amounts added to the FS (for example, additions connected to assets with HP cash flows under Matching Adjustment 4.16, or additions made for other reasons under Matching Adjustment 4.17). [#SRC:dd04e755dbd1506a] Separately, a firm is allowed to increase the fundamental spread above the level calculated under 4.10 to 4.16 if that increase is needed to make sure the fundamental spread covers all risks the firm keeps. [#TGT:26262b6ce882a0b1] Putting these points together: the method stays stable, but the firm should revisit assumptions and can raise the fundamental spread where necessary so retained risks are fully covered. [#SRC:dd04e755dbd1506a] [#TGT:26262b6ce882a0b1]
source_text: Chapter 4 of the Matching Adjustment Part of the PRA rulebook (restating as rules the relevant provisions of the IRPR regulations) sets out how the MA and FS should be calculated for the purpose of determining TPs. While the PRA considers that the MA calculation method should not change in stress conditions, firms should consider if the assumptions used to calculate the MA and FS for the TP calculation, including any additions to the FS (either for assets with HP cash flows as per Matching Adjustment 4.16 or for other reasons as per Matching Adjustment 4.17 ), remain appropriate in stress conditions.
target_text: A firm may increase the fundamental spread calculated under 4.10 to 4.16 where necessary to ensure it covers all risks retained by the firm .

question: For a subsidiary assessing its Senior Management Functions (SMFs) and maintaining governance documentation, how should it treat its Statements of Responsibilities (SoR) in light of the fact that Statements of Responsibilities are those required by section 60(2A) of FSMA, and what related documentation and allocation expectations apply?
gold_answer: A subsidiary should treat its Statements of Responsibilities (SoR) as the Statements of Responsibilities required by section 60(2A) of FSMA, and it should keep those SoR current as part of its broader senior management governance arrangements. [#TGT:9de8b5441f652d6e] In practice, the subsidiary is expected to ensure it has an appropriate number of SMFs that reflects its size, complexity, and governance structure, and to do so consistently with the principles in SS28/15 on strengthening individual accountability in banking. [#SRC:f199857a7c43ed1d] Alongside calibrating SMFs, the subsidiary should ensure that both its Management Responsibilities Maps and its SoR are up to date. [#SRC:f199857a7c43ed1d] It should also allocate responsibilities in accordance with the Allocation of Responsibilities Part of the PRA Rulebook and SS28/15, using the up-to-date SoR and Management Responsibilities Maps as the key governance artefacts supporting that allocation. [#SRC:f199857a7c43ed1d] Because the SoR are specifically the FSMA section 60(2A) Statements of Responsibilities, the subsidiary’s obligation to keep SoR current should be understood as maintaining those section 60(2A) documents in an up-to-date state within its accountability framework. [#TGT:9de8b5441f652d6e]
source_text: A subsidiary should ensure that they have an appropriate number of SMFs according to its size, complexity, and governance structure, in line with the principles outlined in SS28/15 ‘Strengthening individual accountability in banking’ . 34 Firms should particularly ensure that Management Responsibilities Maps and Statements of Responsibilities (SoR) are up to date and that responsibilities are allocated in accordance with the Allocation of Responsibilities Part of the PRA Rulebook and SS28/15 . 35
target_text: 35. Statements of Responsibilities are those required by section 60 (2A) of FSMA: https://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2000/8/section/60 .

question: If a firm is in a group covered by 2.1(3), does it still have to follow Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 2.1 and 2.2 for its important group business services when 22.2, 22.3 and 22.4 do not apply because the parent undertaking is based in an overseas jurisdiction designated under regulation 11 (linked to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations) and regulation 14(3) applies?
gold_answer: Yes—the text sets up two different effects that you must apply together: one creates an operational resilience compliance duty for important group business services, and the other removes the application of certain numbered provisions in a specific overseas-supervision situation. [#TGT:3ae851f798bf5091] When the firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3) (noting the “subject to 22.5” wording), the firm must also comply with Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 2.1 and 2.2 in relation to its important group business services. [#TGT:3ae851f798bf5091] Separately, for a firm that is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3), 22.2, 22.3 and 22.4 do not apply if the group’s parent undertaking has its head office in a third country that is an overseas jurisdiction designated under regulation 11 in relation to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations for insurance group supervision, and regulation 14(3) applies. [#SRC:b6b6500b2b9939c8] Putting these together, you should not treat the non-application of 22.2–22.4 as cancelling the stated requirement to comply with Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 2.1 and 2.2 for important group business services; instead, you apply the operational resilience duty based on the group coverage, while separately recognizing that 22.2–22.4 are switched off only when the overseas-jurisdiction and regulation 14(3) conditions are met. [#SRC:b6b6500b2b9939c8] [#TGT:3ae851f798bf5091]
source_text: Where a firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(3) , 22.2 , 22.3 and 22.4 do not apply if, the third country in which the group's parent undertaking has its head office is an overseas jurisdiction designated under regulation 11 in relation to regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations in respect of insurance group supervision and paragraph (3) of regulation 14 of the IRPR regulations applies.
target_text: Where a firm is a member of a group covered by 2.1(1) , 2.1(2) or, subject to 22.5 , 2.1(3) , the firm must also comply with Operational Resilience – Solvency II Firms 2.1 and 2.2 in relation to its important group business services .

question: If a firm is dealing with capital instruments that count toward regulatory capital resources or own funds, when does it have to tell the PRA for CET1/AT1 compared with Tier 2, and how does that fit with the Rulebook’s idea of “pre-issuance notification” and “post-notification” in Rules 7A to 7D?
gold_answer: The timing depends on the type of capital instrument, and the difference lines up with the Rulebook’s split between pre-issuance notification and post-notification. [#TGT:b9bc12dacc3dd268] For CET1 and AT1 capital instruments that will count toward regulatory capital resources or own funds (at solo, sub-consolidated, group consolidated level, or any combination), the firm is generally required to notify the PRA at least one month before the planned issuance date or before the planned amendment/variation to the terms. [#SRC:1fbc1202165b9d05] This matches the statement that Rules 7A to 7D require pre-issuance notification for CET1 and AT1 issuances. [#TGT:b9bc12dacc3dd268] For Tier 2 capital instruments that will count toward regulatory capital resources or own funds at those same levels, the firm is generally required to notify the PRA immediately after the instrument is issued or immediately after the terms are amended/varied. [#SRC:1fbc1202165b9d05] That “after the fact” timing aligns with the Rulebook’s description of post-notification for Tier 2 issuances under Rules 7A to 7D. [#TGT:b9bc12dacc3dd268] So, the practical takeaway is: CET1/AT1 notice is sent in advance, while Tier 2 notice is sent right after the event. [#SRC:1fbc1202165b9d05]
source_text: Firms are generally required 6 to notify the PRA at least one month before the intended date of issuance or amendment or variation to the terms of each CET1 or AT1 capital instrument, and immediately after issuing or amending or varying the terms of each Tier 2 capital instrument, that will count towards regulatory capital resources or own funds, either at solo, sub-consolidated or group consolidated level or any combination of these.
target_text: 6. Rules 7A to 7D of Definition of Capital Part of the PRA Rulebook require pre-issuance notification for CET1 and AT1 issuances, and post-notification for Tier 2 issuances.

question: When a credit union reschedules a delinquent loan or capitalises arrears, what is the expected governance action by directors regarding the provisioning amount, and for how long must the relevant provision be kept in place in order to demonstrate accurate compliance with the provisioning requirements in Rules 3.11 and 3.12 of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook?
gold_answer: Directors are expected to take active, ongoing steps to assure themselves that their credit union is accurately complying with the provisioning requirements in Rules 3.11 and 3.12 of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook, including in situations where loan terms are changed. [#SRC:837cf352ecff942f] In the specific case where a delinquent loan is rescheduled or the arrears are capitalised, accurate compliance requires that the provision level that applied immediately before the rescheduling or recapitalisation is not reduced simply because of that restructuring event. [#TGT:bbe5b9ddbc2430ff] Instead, the credit union must keep that pre-change provision in place until the loan has demonstrated sustained performance for a defined period. [#TGT:bbe5b9ddbc2430ff] The required duration is six months of performance following the rescheduling or recapitalisation, after which the credit union may reassess provisioning consistent with the applicable rules. [#TGT:bbe5b9ddbc2430ff] Accordingly, directors should regularly satisfy themselves that the credit union maintains the immediately pre-rescheduling (or pre-recapitalisation) provision throughout that six-month performance window as part of their oversight of accurate compliance with Rules 3.11 and 3.12. [#SRC:837cf352ecff942f] [#TGT:bbe5b9ddbc2430ff]
source_text: The PRA expects that all directors regularly satisfy themselves that their credit union accurately complies with the provisioning requirements in Rules 3.11 and 3.12 of the Credit Unions Part of the PRA Rulebook.
target_text: Where a delinquent loan is rescheduled or the arrears capitalised, the provision a credit union is required to make immediately prior to the rescheduling or recapitalisation must be maintained until the loan has performed for six months.

question: If a firm trades cash equities or cash bonds (which can create settlement risk even though they don’t attract counterparty credit risk), what happens if the firm doesn’t manage settlement risk well for products outside its advanced CCR model and still uses zero capital for that risk?
gold_answer: If the firm is dealing in products like cash equities or cash bonds—examples of products that can create settlement risk without attracting counterparty credit risk—the firm still needs to manage the settlement risk effectively. [#TGT:5059cf1db1f509c9] When that settlement risk comes from products outside the scope of an advanced CCR model, and the firm’s settlement-risk management is not adequate, the PRA may question whether it is appropriate for the firm to apply a zero capital requirement to that settlement risk. [#SRC:6c6326c6d1c86320] Adequate management is illustrated by controls such as pre-deal checking, defined limit frameworks, and appropriate reporting; weaknesses in these kinds of measures are the type of situation in which the PRA may intervene. [#SRC:6c6326c6d1c86320] If the PRA does challenge the zero capital approach, it can require the firm to hold additional capital under Pillar 2 to address the settlement risk. [#SRC:6c6326c6d1c86320] In other words, the fact that these products’ settlement risk does not attract counterparty credit risk does not, by itself, prevent a Pillar 2 capital add-on if settlement-risk controls are not strong for exposures outside the advanced CCR model. [#TGT:5059cf1db1f509c9]
source_text: Where firms do not adequately manage settlement risk arising from products outside the scope of an advanced CCR model 13 (eg through pre-deal checking, defined limit frameworks, appropriate reporting), the PRA may challenge the appropriateness of a zero capital requirement for such risk and require firms to hold additional capital under Pillar 2.
target_text: 13. This would include products (eg cash equities and cash bonds) that can result in settlement risk that does not attract counterparty credit risk.

question: If I’m checking the SoP links to EIOPA materials, do I need to look at EIOPA updates made after the transition period, and what should I do about older Guidelines and Recommendations from predecessor committees that aren’t in the appendices?
gold_answer: For SoP purposes, you should rely on the EIOPA Guidelines and Recommendations that were in place at the end of the transition period, using the SoP links, and you should not treat later EIOPA changes or new EIOPA materials issued after that point as relevant to the SoP. [#TGT:6e9c30ab0bba7980] However, you also need to recognize that the appendices are not a complete inventory, so the fact that something is missing from the lists does not mean it can be ignored. [#SRC:fa6efa5299a687b0] Specifically, Guidelines and Recommendations made by predecessor committees to the ESAs may be absent from the appendices, yet firms and FMIs are expected to continue complying with them where relevant. [#SRC:fa6efa5299a687b0] The key limiter is that this continuation expectation does not apply if those predecessor materials have been revoked or replaced—either by later Guidelines and Recommendations or by other legislation. [#SRC:fa6efa5299a687b0] Putting both points together: use the SoP links as the Bank and PRA’s acknowledged EIOPA source for end-of-transition materials, but separately assess any relevant predecessor-committee materials that may not appear in the appendices, unless they have been revoked or superseded. [#TGT:6e9c30ab0bba7980] [#SRC:fa6efa5299a687b0]
source_text: The lists in Appendices 1 to 3 are not exhaustive. For example, Guidelines and Recommendations that were made by the predecessor committees 2 to the ESAs are not included on this list but firms and FMIs should continue, where relevant, to comply with them, unless they have been revoked or superseded by later Guidelines and Recommendations, or by other legislation.
target_text: Links to EIOPA Guidelines and Recommendations in place as at the end of the transition period are available below. Changes to existing EU Guidelines and Recommendations, and new Guidelines and Recommendations, issued by EIOPA after the end of the transition period are not relevant for the purposes of this SoP. The Bank and PRA acknowledge EIOPA as the source of these materials.

question: When determining the amount of the long-term insurance liability for each contract, under what circumstances may a retrospective calculation be used instead of the default prospective calculation, and what demonstration (if any) is required to justify that choice?
gold_answer: The default position is that the amount of the long-term insurance liability is to be calculated prospectively for each contract, meaning the starting assumption is a prospective calculation on a contract-by-contract basis. [#SRC:72c3af495575a5fb] A retrospective calculation is permitted only as an exception to that default, and only in limited circumstances tied to the feasibility and prudence of the prospective approach. [#TGT:30f622a929df3844] Specifically, a retrospective calculation may be used where a prospective method cannot be applied to a particular type of contract or benefit, which links the contract-level determination requirement to a contract/benefit-type limitation on method selection. [#SRC:72c3af495575a5fb] [#TGT:30f622a929df3844] Alternatively, even if a prospective method could be applied, a retrospective calculation may be used where it can be demonstrated that the liabilities produced would be no lower than the amount that would be required by a prudent prospective calculation; in that case, the justification hinges on demonstrating a non-lower outcome relative to a prudent prospective benchmark. [#TGT:30f622a929df3844] In all cases, the prospective calculation remains the baseline method for determining the long-term insurance liability for each contract, and the retrospective approach is only available within the stated exception conditions. [#SRC:72c3af495575a5fb] [#TGT:30f622a929df3844]
source_text: Subject to 7.2 , 7.3 and 7.4 , the amount of the long-term insurance liability must be determined for each contract by a prospective calculation.
target_text: A retrospective calculation may only be applied to determine the liabilities where a prospective method cannot be applied to a particular type of contract or benefit, or where it can be demonstrated that the resulting amount of liabilities would be no lower than would be required by a prudent prospective calculation.

question: If a firm has big exposures to companies in its own group, what is the normal rule for how those exposures are treated, and what does the firm need to apply for if it wants a higher limit—plus which named document (with month and year) is pointed to for “Large Exposures”?
gold_answer: Normally, a firm’s exposures to entities in its own group are not treated as a special category; they are generally treated like exposures to a third party and therefore are subject to the large exposure limits. [#SRC:27a742d1f4627dc1] If the firm wants to use a higher large exposure limit for certain entities within its group, it can do so only by applying to the PRA for a non-core large exposures group permission, and the higher limit is available only where those group entities meet the relevant conditions tied to that permission. [#SRC:27a742d1f4627dc1] The text also points to a specific supervisory statement for the large exposures topic: SS16/13, called ‘Large Exposures’, dated June 2018. [#TGT:998aae35b45397cf] Putting these points together, the compliance approach is to treat intra-group exposures as if they were to an outside counterparty unless the PRA grants the non-core large exposures group permission, and to use the referenced SS16/13 ‘Large Exposures’ (June 2018) as the named supervisory statement associated with this large exposures framework. [#SRC:27a742d1f4627dc1] [#TGT:998aae35b45397cf]
source_text: A firm’s exposures to entities in its own group are generally treated as exposures to a third party and are subject to large exposure limits. Firms can however apply to the PRA for a non-core large exposures group permission, which allows firms to apply a higher large exposure limit to certain entities within their group provided these entities meet certain conditions. 45

question: If a controller or proposed controller is an investment manager buying or selling listed shares as part of fund management and is following directions 2.1 and 2.3, what form can they use, and what does the section 178 notice need to include and be sent with?
gold_answer: For an investment manager in this listed-shares fund management situation, the PRA allows use of a specific Controller’s form, and the section 178 notice must be completed to match the information and document requirements of the relevant Controller’s Form. [#SRC:3d54441b14fbefda] [#TGT:6dd8365d28ebc407] The PRA’s direction for this context is that where a controller or proposed controller that is an investment manager is complying with the directions in 2.1 and 2.3 in connection with acquiring or disposing of listed shares in the course of its fund management activity, it may use the Controller’s form at 6.5. [#SRC:3d54441b14fbefda] Separately, the PRA directs that a section 178 notice submitted to the PRA in accordance with section 178(1) of FSMA must contain the information and be accompanied by the documents required by the Controller’s Form approved for the relevant application. [#TGT:6dd8365d28ebc407] Putting these together, the permitted form in the investment-manager listed-shares case is the Controller’s form at 6.5, and the notice should include the information and supporting documents that the applicable Controller’s Form requires. [#SRC:3d54441b14fbefda] [#TGT:6dd8365d28ebc407]
source_text: Where a controller or proposed controller that is an investment manager is complying with the directions in 2.1 and 2.3 in connection with the acquiring or disposal of listed shares in the course its fund management activity, the PRA directs that it may use the Controller’s form at 6.5 .
target_text: The PRA directs that a section 178 notice submitted to the PRA in accordance with section 178(1) of FSMA must contain the information and be accompanied by such documents as are required by the Controller’s Form approved for the relevant application.

question: For a third country CRR firm, how should responsibility for allocating all third country CRR firm prescribed responsibilities be handled, and to whom must those prescribed responsibilities be allocated (in terms of the type of persons who perform the roles)?
