target_text: (1) A firm must not allocate a prescribed responsibility to a person who performs an FCA other overall responsibility senior management function .

question: Where the PRA has consented to a transferee society proceeding by board resolution (so that it is exempt from putting Merger Resolutions and sending a Schedule 16 Statement to its members), what timetable-management steps should the societies still follow from the point their boards resolve to seek a merger, and what member notifications must be included in the Merger Document?
gold_answer: Even where the PRA has consented to a transferee society proceeding by board resolution—removing the need to put Merger Resolutions to members and to send a Schedule 16 Statement to its members—the merger should still be managed against a structured timetable and member-notification sequence. [#SRC:98fdd2a7fe5b0420] As a practical planning baseline, the end-to-end path from board decision through approval of the Schedule 16 Statement, a general meeting, and a confirmation hearing to the effective date is generally not expected to take less than six months, so the societies should plan on that scale when setting milestones. [#TGT:513958170c8d776a] The societies should meet with the PRA’s staff as soon as their boards have resolved to seek a merger and agree a provisional timetable, which can then be fixed by the time the Schedule 16 Statement is approved. [#TGT:513958170c8d776a] Regardless of the board-resolution consent scenario described, members must be notified (via the Merger Document) of both the provisionally set date for the confirmation hearing and the proposed completion date of the merger. [#TGT:513958170c8d776a]
source_text: The probable sequence of events is described more fully in section ‘ Timetable ’. The case where the PRA has consented to a transferee society proceeding by board resolution, and thereby exempting it from the requirement to put Merger Resolutions, and sending a Schedule 16 Statement, to its members, is described in paragraphs 3.149 – 3.152 .
target_text: The time taken to complete a merger will vary from case to case. As a general rule of thumb, it is unlikely that a merger can proceed from board decision through approval of the Schedule 16 Statement, general meeting and confirmation hearing, to the effective date, in less than six months. It is essential to the good and orderly management of a merger that the societies concerned meet with the PRA’s staff as soon as their boards have resolved to seek a merger, and agree upon a provisional timetable. This can then be fixed by the time the Schedule 16 Statement is approved. The members can then be notified, as they must be, of the date provisionally set for the confirmation hearing and of the proposed date of completion of the merger in the Merger Document.

question: When a firm (and, where applicable, a UK holding company) reports group information that includes more than one firm using an internal model, what must be submitted to the PRA, how often, what must it contain, and under which rulebook provisions and instructions must it be submitted?
gold_answer: In the scenario where firms and, where applicable, UK holding companies report information on a group that includes more than one firm using an internal model, they must submit template AoC.01 to the PRA on an annual basis. [#TGT:d0d445db94d0c556] The submission must set out the analysis of change referenced in Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 13A and must include both quantitative information and a supporting qualitative analysis. [#TGT:d0d445db94d0c556] AoC.01 is the PRA’s analysis of change template that firms complete with key information about movements in SCR, so the content should address the movement in SCR in the format of that template. [#SRC:282806b2f50a9291] The submission must be made in line with the instructions in section AoC.01 of Chapter 10, and it must also be submitted in accordance with Articles 19 and 35 of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook. [#TGT:d0d445db94d0c556] [#SRC:282806b2f50a9291]
source_text: The PRA has provided an analysis of change template, named AoC.01, for firms to complete with key information regarding the movement in SCR and submit in accordance with Articles 19 and 35 of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook.
target_text: Firms and, where applicable, UK holding companies reporting information on a group which includes more than one firm using an internal model must submit to the PRA annually template AoC.01 setting out the analysis of change referred to in Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models 13A , including both quantitative information and a supporting qualitative analysis, in accordance with the instructions set out in section AoC.01 of Chapter 10 .

question: When the PRA assesses an internal model application or a firm’s continued compliance with calibration standards 22 and internal model requirements 23 for internal model permissions, how should the firm incorporate the PRA’s requested EVT-in-stress test into its regular cycle of internal model validation (including sensitivity testing and performance monitoring) so as to support assurance that the MA in stress is not overstated?
gold_answer: A firm should embed the PRA-requested EVT-in-stress test within its regular internal model validation cycle so it functions as a recurring validation tool that supports the firm’s ability to demonstrate appropriate capital requirements and provides assurance that the MA in stress is not overstated. [#SRC:197d09dc7abf48b4] [#TGT:5b30ae70a80bf3bb] In practice, the EVT-in-stress exercise should be treated as part of the firm’s ongoing validation toolkit, because the PRA indicates it will ask firms to apply a test based on the EVT in stress when assessing internal model applications and continued compliance with the relevant calibration standards and internal model requirements for permissions. [#SRC:197d09dc7abf48b4] To integrate it into the required validation cycle, the firm should align the EVT-in-stress test with the cycle elements that already must exist: monitoring internal model performance and reviewing whether the model specification remains appropriate; testing model results against experience; operating an effective statistical validation process that enables the firm to demonstrate to the PRA that capital requirements are appropriate; and testing sensitivity of results to changes in key underlying assumptions (which can be informed by stressed comparisons of economic value and Effective Value). [#TGT:5b30ae70a80bf3bb] [#SRC:197d09dc7abf48b4] The firm should also ensure the data used for the EVT-in-stress work is assessed for accuracy, completeness, and appropriateness as part of the same validation cycle. [#TGT:5b30ae70a80bf3bb]
source_text: The PRA considers reassessment of the EVT in stress, in particular the comparison of stressed economic value and Effective Value in (iv) above, to be a helpful validation exercise that could contribute to firms meeting the internal model requirements (see Chapter 14 of the Solvency Capital Requirement – Internal Models Part of the PRA Rulebook). When assessing internal model applications and firms’ continued compliance with the calibration standards 22 and internal model requirements 23 relevant for granting internal model permissions, the PRA will ask firms to apply a test based on the EVT in stress, to assist in providing assurance that the amount of MA in stress is not overstated. Firms may wish to consider adding an EVT in stress to their regular suite of validation tools.
target_text: (1) A firm must have in place a regular cycle of internal model validation which includes: (a) monitoring the performance of the internal model , reviewing the ongoing appropriateness of its specification and testing its results against experience; (b) an effective statistical process for validating the internal model which enables the firm to demonstrate to the PRA that the resulting capital requirements are appropriate; (c) an analysis of the stability of the internal model and, in particular, the testing of the sensitivity of the results of the internal model to changes in key underlying assumptions; and (d) an assessment of the accuracy, completeness and appropriateness of the data used by the internal model .

question: Where a merger’s terms provide for (i) compensation to directors or other officers for loss of office or income and (ii) bonus payments requiring members’ approval as part of the Merger Resolutions, how should the society structure member approvals, including when bonus approval must appear in the Merger Resolutions of only certain societies versus all participating societies?
gold_answer: Member approvals should be structured so that compensation for loss of office/income is approved through a distinct special resolution, while bonus payments are approved through the Merger Resolutions in the manner dictated by the prescribed-limit test. [#SRC:64a6d4e1a3eca833] Specifically, if the merger terms include compensation to directors or other officers for loss of office or income, those proposed payments must be put to members under a separate special resolution (i.e., not merely embedded within the general merger approval). [#SRC:64a6d4e1a3eca833] In parallel, members’ approval of bonus payments is required as part of the Merger Resolutions. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] The placement of that bonus approval across the participating societies depends on whether the total gross cost of the proposed bonus(es), calculated without adjusting for prospective corporation tax recovery, is within the prescribed limit. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] If the total gross cost is within the prescribed limit, the bonus approval need only be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of the society whose funds are to be distributed. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] If the total gross cost exceeds the prescribed limit, the bonus approval must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society. [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8] This approach ensures the distinct approval route for loss-of-office compensation is maintained while bonus approvals are correctly allocated across Merger Resolutions based on the prescribed-limit threshold. [#SRC:64a6d4e1a3eca833] [#TGT:9dfe512afd4bf0e8]
source_text: If the terms of a merger include provision for the payment of compensation to directors or other officers for loss of office or of income, then the proposed payments must be approved by a separate special resolution. A further special resolution may also be required if there is to be a distribution to members which exceeds the limits described in paragraph 3.107 .
target_text: The members approval of bonus payments is required as part of the Merger Resolutions (see section 96(4) to (6) of the 1986 Act) and see paragraph 3.59 for the PRA’s view of what may constitute a bonus). If it exceeds that limit then it must be included in each of the Merger Resolutions of each participating society. question: In a transfer to a specially formed successor company, how must the terms of the transfer address the society’s holding of shares by the time the society dissolves, and how does that requirement interact with the society’s ability to notify a later dissolution date in its vesting-date notice (including any limits on business activity after the vesting date)?
gold_answer: The transfer documentation must be drafted so that it ensures the society will no longer hold any shares in the specially formed successor company by the date on which the society is to dissolve. [#SRC:6b46a0ab65f37c08] In parallel, once the PRA has confirmed the transfer it will notify the FCA and the society, and the society must itself notify the PRA and the FCA of the vesting date no later than seven days before that date. [#TGT:44f3b2962ff383a8] Unless the society gives a notice that specifies a later dissolution date, the society is dissolved on the vesting date; however, if it is necessary to facilitate disposal of the society’s shares in its successor, the society may include in the vesting-date notice a later dissolution date, and dissolution then occurs on that later date. [#TGT:44f3b2962ff383a8] The share-disposal linkage is that the transfer terms must still secure that the society ceases to hold any shares by the (possibly later) dissolution date identified through this notice mechanism. [#SRC:6b46a0ab65f37c08] If the society uses the later-dissolution option, it must stop transacting business from the notified vesting date, except business needed to dispose of its shares in its successor. [#TGT:44f3b2962ff383a8]
source_text: The terms of the transfer must include provision to secure that the society ceases to hold any shares in the specially formed successor company by the date on which the society is to dissolve (Section 100(11) of the 1986 Act). The provisions of the 1986 Act concerning the dissolution of the society and the disposal of any shares in its successor are discussed in section ‘ Notification and Dissolution ’.
target_text: When the PRA has confirmed a transfer (whether voluntary or under direction) it will notify the FCA and the society concerned. Section 97(8) of the 1986 Act requires the society to notify the PRA and the FCA of the vesting date, and it must do so no later than seven days before that date, and, unless a notice is given under subsection (10), subsection (9) provides that the society shall be dissolved on that date. Subsection (10) provides that, if necessary for the purpose of facilitating the disposal of its shares in its successor, the society may include, in the notice of the vesting date, notice of a later date for the dissolution of the society, and it is on this later date that the society is dissolved. A society which gives such a notice must cease to transact any business as from the notified vesting date, except such as may be necessary to dispose of its shares in its successor.

question: When 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies so that specified requirements must be applied “with any necessary changes” at the level of the group, how should a firm ensure its risk-management system addresses risks both individually and on an aggregated basis, and which referenced requirement set is being applied at group level to support that outcome?
gold_answer: If 2.1(1) or 2.1(2) applies, the firm must apply the listed requirement sets “with any necessary changes” at the level of the group, meaning the firm should treat those requirements as operating on a group-wide basis rather than only on a solo-entity basis. [#SRC:bb599b0cccb14552] In that group-level context, the firm’s risk-management system must be designed and maintained so it can identify, measure, monitor, manage, and report risks continuously both for each relevant unit (individual level) and across the group as a whole (aggregated level), including how risks interact with each other (interdependencies). [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca] Practically, this means the group-level application should be used to ensure the risk-management system includes strategies, processes, and reporting procedures that work across the group and can produce both entity-specific and consolidated risk views on an ongoing basis. [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca] The referenced requirement sets that are expressly to be applied at group level include, among others, Conditions Governing Business (including 2.2 to 2.6 and 2A.1 to 2A.6), Fitness and Propriety (including 2.1 to 2.3, 4.1, 4.3 and 4.4), Allocation of Responsibilities 4, and Key Function Holder – Notifications 2 to 6 (in accordance with 17.4). [#SRC:bb599b0cccb14552]

question: For a UK subsidiary of a group based outside of the UK, how should the recovery plan describe (i) the UK governance framework for monitoring indicators and taking action, including when decisions are escalated to group level, and (ii) the SMR accountability arrangements for recovery planning, including the named executive’s responsibilities for the recovery plan and resolution pack and engagement with the PRA?
gold_answer: A UK subsidiary of a group based outside of the UK should set out a UK-specific governance framework that explains how indicators are monitored and how actions are triggered, and it should also specify the point at which decisions are escalated to group level. [#SRC:540b8d2e62cc1fe2] In parallel, because recovery planning is treated as a prescribed responsibility under the SMR, the firm should identify a named executive who is accountable for the recovery plan and resolution pack and who oversees the internal governance processes supporting them. [#TGT:084062e615cc02e8] The accountable executive director should be clearly identified as responsible for the recovery plan and for serving as the firm’s contact point with the authorities on recovery plan matters. [#TGT:084062e615cc02e8] The PRA’s expectations for this accountable person include being answerable for the quality of the recovery plan, ensuring it is structured to be usable by senior executives and board members in a stress, driving improvements (including in response to PRA feedback), and managing the firm’s engagement with the PRA on recovery planning issues. [#TGT:084062e615cc02e8] For UK subsidiaries of non-UK groups, the plan should also reflect the PRA’s expectation that the subsidiary meets relevant SMR-related requirements referenced for such firms, aligning the UK governance framework and escalation arrangements with clearly assigned responsibilities under the SMR. [#SRC:540b8d2e62cc1fe2]
source_text: (vi) The plan should include a UK governance framework for monitoring the indicators and taking action where appropriate. For UK subsidiaries of groups based outside of the UK, in meeting expectations set out in Chapter 2 (viii) , the PRA expects firms to set out when decisions would be escalated to group level. In addition, the PRA expects UK subsidiaries of groups based outside of the UK to meet requirements set out in Chapter 2 (xiii) (c) in relation to responsibilities under the SMR.
target_text: Firms are reminded that recovery planning is a prescribed responsibility under the SMR which means that there should be a named executive at each firm that is accountable for the recovery plan and resolution pack and for overseeing the internal processes regarding their governance. 18 Firms should identify the accountable executive director responsible for the firm’s recovery plan and for acting as the firm’s contact point with the authorities on its recovery plan. The PRA has observed that this is typically the CEO, CFO or CRO. The PRA will hold this person accountable for the quality of the recovery plan, for the plan being structured so as to be usable by senior executives and board members in a stress, for making improvements to the recovery plan (including in response to the PRA’s feedback) and for the firm’s engagement with the PRA on recovery planning issues.

question: At the point of initial investment, if a firm cannot develop a robust methodology for the addition to the FS due to data scarcity, how should it reconcile proposing a simpler (standard) methodology with the expectation to model a term structure, and what demonstration is needed to justify using a uniform allowance instead?
gold_answer: A firm that cannot build a robust methodology for the addition to the FS at the point of initial investment (for example because of data scarcity) may propose a simpler (standard) methodology for calculating the FS, but it should still treat term-structure modelling as the default expectation unless it can justify a uniform allowance. [#SRC:43891e9059ef7894] [#TGT:479d238324e3667c] In practice, the firm can start with a standard approach (and include safeguards aimed at protecting the quality of matching), while assessing whether it can meet the conditions for not modelling a term structure. [#SRC:43891e9059ef7894] [#TGT:479d238324e3667c] To rely on a uniform allowance rather than modelling a term structure for the addition to the FS, the firm needs to be able to demonstrate two points: (1) that using a uniform allowance would not materially affect the adequacy of the allowance for risks arising from cash flow uncertainty, and (2) that it would not materially affect either the assessment of the quality of asset and liability cash flow matching or the results of the PRA’s Matching Tests. [#TGT:479d238324e3667c] Where the firm proceeds with a standard methodology due to initial-investment constraints, the PRA indicates it does not necessarily expect the firm to go beyond a standard methodology to model a term structure as referenced in the earlier paragraph, but the firm must still align its approach with the term-structure expectation or the uniform-allowance demonstration. [#SRC:43891e9059ef7894] [#TGT:479d238324e3667c]
source_text: The PRA understands that, at the point of initial investment, in many cases it may not be possible to develop a robust methodology for the addition to the FS, for example due to data scarcity. Firms may therefore propose a simpler (standard) methodology for calculating the FS, together with any safeguards that could mitigate the risks to the quality of matching. The PRA does not necessarily expect a firm to go beyond a standard methodology to model a term structure as set out in paragraph 5.21 above.
target_text: Firms should model a term structure for the addition to the FS unless it can be demonstrated that a uniform allowance would not materially affect the adequacy of the allowance for the risks arising from cash flow uncertainty, and that a uniform allowance would not materially affect the assessment of the quality of asset and liability cash flow matching or the results of the PRA’s Matching Tests.

question: When a TWD firm writes its recovery plan, what does it need to say about the TWD option (including the active and passive wind-down periods and the cost/capital/liquidity impacts), and how do the firm’s TWD capabilities fit in for carrying out the recovery plan and BRP in real-life situations?
gold_answer: In its recovery plan, a TWD firm should describe the TWD option in a way that makes it easy to carry out in a stress, and it should back that plan with TWD capabilities that let it develop and execute the option in real-life circumstances, including for the BRP. [#SRC:e73d3db81c430c67] [#TGT:896c93bcd423e6b8] The plan should explain the TWD option and, where relevant, include the playbook so implementation in stress is straightforward. [#SRC:e73d3db81c430c67] The plan should also quantify the costs of the wind-down and set out the impacts on the TWD firm’s projected capital and liquidity resources across the wind-down period, which runs from the moment the TWD option is executed until the firm’s trading activities have been wound down. [#SRC:e73d3db81c430c67] For clarity and execution, the wind-down period should be split into: (1) an active wind-down period, ending when the firm has exited all positions it can exit without undue costs; and (2) a passive wind-down period, when the firm hedges exposures of remaining rump positions where possible until they expire. [#SRC:e73d3db81c430c67] Separately, the firm should maintain TWD capabilities that enable it to develop and execute the TWD option in a variety of real-life circumstances, and it should use those capabilities to help develop and execute both its recovery plan and its BRP. [#TGT:896c93bcd423e6b8]
source_text: The TWD option should be explained in the TWD firm’s recovery plan, including the playbook where relevant, such that the TWD option would be easily implemented in a stress. The quantification of the costs of the wind-down, set out in more detail in Chapter 4 , and any impacts on the TWD firm’s projected capital and liquidity resources throughout the period from the time at which the TWD option is executed to the time at which the TWD firm’s trading activities have been wound down (hereinafter referred to as the ‘wind-down period’), should also be set out in the TWD firm’s recovery plan. 14 The wind-down period can be split into the period from the time at which the TWD option is executed to the time at which the TWD firm has exited all the positions it can exit without incurring undue costs (hereinafter referred to as the ‘active wind-down period’); and the rest of the wind-down period, during which the firm hedges the exposures of the remaining ‘rump’ positions (insofar as this is possible) until they expire (hereinafter referred to as the ‘passive wind-down period’).
target_text: TWD firms should have TWD capabilities that will enable them to develop and execute the TWD option in a variety of real-life circumstances. TWD firms should use their TWD capabilities to help them to develop and execute their recovery plan and BRP.

question: When assessing the operational resilience of the firm and group, how should the firm treat risks arising elsewhere in the group (including intragroup outsourcing or other inter-affiliate arrangements) in relation to its ability to deliver “important business services” versus “critical operations,” and which UK entity types are those two service concepts tied to?
gold_answer: In assessing operational resilience, the firm should explicitly consider how risks originating elsewhere in the group—including those created or transmitted through intragroup outsourcing or other inter-affiliate arrangements—could impair the firm’s ability to continue delivering the services that matter most, and it should map that assessment to the correct service concept based on the relevant UK entity type. [#SRC:2799da281c0d7ac4] “Important business services” should be treated as the category of services defined in the Operational Continuity Part of the PRA Rulebook, and this framing applies to CRR firms, described here as UK subsidiaries of international groups. [#TGT:083adfa9d1ebdfbf] “Critical operations” should be treated as the category of services defined in the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision’s Principles for Operational Resilience (March 2021), and this framing is relevant for UK branches. [#TGT:083adfa9d1ebdfbf] Practically, the firm’s group-risk analysis should therefore: (i) identify group-originated risks that could disrupt delivery; (ii) include dependencies created by intragroup outsourcing and inter-affiliate arrangements; and (iii) classify the impacted services as “important business services” for CRR firms (UK subsidiaries) or as “critical operations” for UK branches, so the resilience assessment is aligned to the applicable service definition. [#SRC:2799da281c0d7ac4] [#TGT:083adfa9d1ebdfbf]
source_text: the operational resilience of the firm and group, including risks arising elsewhere in the group that may affect the ability of the firm to deliver its important business services or critical operations (such as those provided through intragroup outsourcing or other inter-affiliate arrangements); 25
target_text: 25. Important business services refers to services as defined in the Operational Continuity Part of the PRA Rulebook which applies to CRR firms – ie UK subsidiaries of international groups. Critical operations refers to services as defined in the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision’s ‘Principles for Operational Resilience’ (March 2021): https://www.bis.org/bcbs/publ/d516.pdf , and is relevant for UK branches.

question: If a firm is allowed to use a partial or full internal model, what does it have to send the PRA every quarter about model changes, and which template and instructions tell it what to include (including qualitative support)?
gold_answer: If a firm has permission to use a partial or full internal model, it has to send the PRA a quarterly update about changes to that model. [#SRC:6b80f0d656b136bd] The quarterly update must be a summary that covers both minor and major model changes, and it is required under Article 6(3) of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook together with the EIOPA Guidelines on the use of internal models. [#SRC:6b80f0d656b136bd] To provide the information in the required reporting format, firms using an internal model must submit quarterly template QMC.01 in Chapter 9. [#TGT:96395cb1453e2aa2] That template is used to specify information on model changes and to include supporting qualitative information, so the quarterly summary is not just a list of changes but also includes qualitative support. [#TGT:96395cb1453e2aa2] The firm must also follow the instructions in section QMC.01 of Chapter 10, which sets out how to complete the template and what information to provide. [#TGT:96395cb1453e2aa2] In practice, the firm meets the quarterly summary requirement by completing and submitting QMC.01 with the required model-change details and qualitative support to the PRA each quarter. [#SRC:6b80f0d656b136bd] [#TGT:96395cb1453e2aa2]
source_text: In accordance with Article 6(3) of Chapter 2A of the Reporting Part of the PRA Rulebook and the EIOPA Guidelines on the use of internal models, firms with permission to use a partial or full internal model are required to provide a quarterly summary of minor and major model changes to the PRA.
target_text: Firms using an internal model must submit to the PRA quarterly template QMC.01 of Chapter 9 , specifying information on model changes and supporting qualitative information, in accordance with the instructions set out in section QMC.01 of Chapter 10 .

question: If the C17.01/C17.02 reporting instructions tell you to use supervisory disclosures from the EBA website, what UK document should you use instead, and where do you find it online?
gold_answer: You should treat the instruction to use supervisory disclosures from the EBA website as meaning you must use the corresponding disclosure produced by the PRA for those COREP templates. [#SRC:40ad42a86de28e1d] The online location for that PRA disclosure is the “Regulatory reporting – banking sector” page in the prudential regulation section of the Bank of England website, using the specific web address provided. [#TGT:91473ca52a070954] This linkage matters because the COREP instructions for C17.01 and C17.02 explicitly redirect certain non-UK references (including the EBA supervisory disclosure reference) to UK equivalents, so your reporting should be based on the PRA-produced disclosure rather than the EBA publication. [#SRC:40ad42a86de28e1d] In other words, when you see the EBA supervisory disclosure reference in those instructions, you should navigate to the Bank of England prudential regulation area and retrieve the PRA disclosure from the Regulatory reporting – banking sector page, ensuring your template completion uses the UK-referenced source. [#TGT:91473ca52a070954]
source_text: Example occurrences: The CRR COREP instructions for C17.01 and C17.02 (Annexes I and II of PRA Rulebook, Reporting (CRR) Part, Templates and Instructions) contain references to supervisory disclosures published on the EBA website, and the gross domestic product at market prices data published by Eurostat. These references should be read as a reference to the corresponding disclosure produced by the PRA, 4 and the corresponding data published by the Office for National Statistics. question: If a firm is setting up its risk-management system, what does it need to cover so it both (a) includes risks used for the SCR and risks not fully captured there, and (b) meets the requirement that calibration takes account of all quantifiable risks (including the listed minimum risk types)?
gold_answer: The firm needs a risk-management system that is broad enough to cover the risks used in the SCR calculation and also any risks that are not, or not fully, included in that calculation, while also aligning with the calibration expectation that all quantifiable risks the firm faces are taken into account. [#SRC:ec68cf68d094e876] [#TGT:f261181a95a3ca51] The system must be effective and properly integrated into the firm’s organisational structure and decision-making processes, with proper consideration of the persons who have key functions, so that the calibration and risk coverage are embedded in how the firm is run. [#SRC:ec68cf68d094e876] To make this concrete, the calibration requirement says quantifiable risks must be captured and names at least non-life underwriting risk, life underwriting risk, health underwriting risk, market risk, credit risk, and operational risk. [#TGT:f261181a95a3ca51] The risk-management system must also cover at least these areas: underwriting and reserving; asset-liability management; investment risk management (especially derivatives, quasi-derivatives and similar commitments); liquidity risk and concentration risk management; operational risk management; and reinsurance and other risk-mitigation techniques. [#SRC:ec68cf68d094e876] Putting these together, the firm should ensure its listed risk-management areas are used to identify and manage the minimum risk categories and any other quantifiable risks, including those not fully reflected in the SCR calculation. [#SRC:ec68cf68d094e876] [#TGT:f261181a95a3ca51]

question: What does the text say non-executive directors must do (including what “independence of mind” looks like in board decisions), and where is the related EU law reference shown (Article 91(8) of the Capital Requirements Directive 2013/36/EU)?
gold_answer: The text says that all non-executive directors who are members of the management body—whether independent or not—have a binding obligation to act with honesty, integrity, and independence of mind. [#SRC:8e63907640d17c50] It also clarifies that “independence of mind” is not just a label but a pattern of behaviour that shows up especially during board discussions and decision-making, where each board member should be able to reach sound, objective, and independent decisions and judgements. [#SRC:8e63907640d17c50] Alongside that, the same passage ties these expectations to specified internal conduct requirements by stating that non-executive directors are required under Rules 2.1–2.3 and 3.4 in the Conduct Rules Part of the Rulebook to act with integrity, due skill, care and diligence, and to be open and co-operative with regulators. [#SRC:8e63907640d17c50] The related EU law reference is shown separately as a citation to “Article 91(8) Capital Requirements Directive (2013/36/EU),” including a link to the legislation source, which is the explicit place where the EU provision is identified in the provided materials. [#TGT:f668b599884eb746]
source_text: As members of the management body, all non-executive directors, whether independent or not, have a binding obligation to act with honesty, integrity and independence of mind 53 and are required under Rules 2.1 - 2.3 and 3.4 in the Conduct Rules Part of the Rulebook to act with integrity, due skill, care and diligence and to be open and co-operative with regulators 54 . Independence of mind is a pattern of behaviour, shown in particular during discussions and decision making at the board. All members of the board should be able to make their own sound, objective and independent decisions and judgements. 55 Banks should consider the appropriate number of non-executive directors who are significant shareholders or who are appointed or nominated by a significant shareholder.
